newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Prodi to open euro show with Santer.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Prodi to open euro show with Santer.

text.p: Italy's Prime Minister Romano Prodi will inaugurate an exhibition on Europe's planned new single currency in Rome next week with European Commission President Jacques Santer, the Treasury said on Wednesday.

It said President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini, Commissioners Marcelino Oreja, Mario Monti and Emma Bonino, and European Parliament President Jose-Maria Gil-Robles will also attend.
They will inaugurate the three-week exhibition, called "Building Europe Together, from the lira to the euro" next Wednesday (1430 GMT), the statement said.

The opening is part of celebrations in the Italian capital next week to mark the 40th anniversary on March 25 of the signing of the Treaty of Rome, which founded the six-nation European Economic Community (EEC).
European Union foreign ministers will meet in Rome next Tuesday for talks on their latest review of the EU's workings before joining an official celebration of the anniversary.

Prodi and his centre-left government say they will do whatever necessary to ensure Italy's finances are in shape for founder membership of Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU), planned for launch on January 1, 1999.

The government is due to unveil a supplementary budget within the next few weeks to try to achieve a 1997 deficit target of three percent of Gross Domestic Product, a key condition for first wave entry into the currency union.
